item.title: Tributes paid by Captain Sir Tom's family at funeral
item.description: He is described at his funeral as "a beacon of light and hope to the world".

item.title: Budget 2021: Mortgage guarantee to help buyers with 5% deposit
item.description: The chancellor says public finances are facing a "challenge" from the impact of the pandemic.

item.title: Anas Sarwar wins Scottish Labour leadership race
item.description: The Glasgow MSP defeated rival candidate Monica Lennon in the contest to replace Richard Leonard.

item.title: Exeter WW2 bomb: 2,600 homes evacuated
item.description: Royal Navy bomb disposal specialists begin dealing with a 2.5m (8ft) device.

item.title: Coronavirus: Biden's $1.9tn Covid relief bill passes House vote
item.description: The coronavirus aid bill passes despite total Republican opposition, but must now go to the Senate.

item.title: Covid: 'I lost both parents in two weeks'
item.description: Grief is compounded by lockdown and isolation, says Claire Apsey, after losing her parents to Covid.

item.title: Covid jabs reach one million milestone in Wales
item.description: A total of 916,316 people have received at least one dose, and 89,053 of those have had a second dose.

item.title: Nigeria kidnappings: Hunt for 300 girls as second abducted school group freed
item.description: Some 317 girls remain missing in Zamfara state, but 42 people abducted in Niger state are freed.

item.title: Police boss wants cannabis trial for prisoners
item.description: The north Wales commissioner says it could cut addiction and violence, but critics reject the call.

item.title: Tiger Woods car crash: Golfer 'in good spirits' after latest treatment
item.description: The golfer received successful "follow-up procedures" following Tuesday's serious car crash in LA.

item.title: Lady Gaga's dogs found safe after armed robbery
item.description: The US singer's two French bulldogs were stolen after gunmen attacked and wounded her dog walker.

item.title: Week in pictures: 20-26 February 2021
item.description: A selection of striking images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Budget 2021: BBC editors on what to expect
item.description: BBC editors Faisal Islam and Simon Jack tell us what Chancellor Rishi Sunak might have in store.

item.title: Venice: Low tides leave canals dry
item.description: In stark contrast to floods in December, some of the city's boats and gondolas are beached.

item.title: How TikTok is powering Duncan Laurence's Eurovision winner
item.description: Duncan Laurence won Eurovision with his song Arcade, which is now being powered by TikTok.

item.title: Michael Collins' wolf slippers spark Twitter storm
item.description: The emergence of the Irish revolutionary's bright blue plush puppies stunned Irish Twitter users.

item.title: Billy Monger completes 'epic' Comic Relief challenge
item.description: The racing driver, who had both legs amputated in 2017, has walked, cycled and kayaked 140 miles.

item.title: The Papers: Over-40s April jab and 'happy as Harry'
item.description: Saturday's papers give their view of the Duke of Sussex's candid interview with James Corden.

item.title: Texas sea turtles released back into sea after cold front eases
item.description: Thousands of "cold-stunned" turtles were rescued as temperatures dropped to record lows this month.

item.title: Golden Globes: Celebrity make-up artists on their job in the pandemic
item.description: Hollywood make-up artists on their experiences of working in the time of Covid-19.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... Is Facebook too powerful?
item.description: Ros Atkins looks at the consequences of Facebook's power on events in Myanmar, Washington DC and Australia.

item.title: How Bitcoin's vast energy use could burst its bubble
item.description: Could the cryptocurrency's huge electricity consumption also sink it?

item.title: Hotel quarantine: Isolation and brown paper bags
item.description: What's it like and what can you eat inside the UK's quarantine hotels?

item.title: Covid-19: How would an NHS vaccine passport app work?
item.description: There is growing speculation that a certificate scheme could be built into the main NHS app.

item.title: Brexit: Why Irish freight trade is avoiding Britain
item.description: Irish freight is being shipped directly to Europe to avoid Brexit bureaucracy.

item.title: Monsters, mania and the unstoppable march of Pokémon
item.description: Several waves of Pokémania have swept the globe, keeping this lucrative franchise relevant for 25 years.

item.title: Salmond and Sturgeon: How the best of political double acts fell apart
item.description: The enviable political duo who ran Scotland together is now long gone. So, what went wrong?

item.title: Jamal Khashoggi: How intelligence report could dent US-Saudi ties for years
item.description: The release of the US intelligence probe into the Khashoggi murder deepens diplomatic difficulties.

item.title: Covid-19: Are 'hate crimes' against Asian Americans on the rise?
item.description: Covid-related attacks directed at Asian Americans have escalated in the US - here's what's happening.

item.title: LGBT in the forces: 'It was a very scary time'
item.description: More than 20 years on, how has military culture changed after allowing the LGBT community to serve?

item.title: Dog theft: 'I can't give up looking for her'
item.description: After Lady Gaga's bulldogs were stolen, victims in the UK share their stories with BBC Radio 5 Live.

item.title: Amazon rainforest plots sold via Facebook Marketplace ads
item.description: Protected land reserved for Brazil's indigenous communities is being traded on the social network.

item.title: Who is Shamima Begum and how do you lose your UK citizenship?
item.description: Ms Begum travelled to Syria to join the so-called Islamic State group in 2015.

item.title: 'We couldn’t afford fertility treatment so we risked finding a sperm donor on Facebook'
item.description: The high cost of fertility treatment leads some to find donors on social media, even though it's risky and could be illegal.

item.title: MLM schemes in the UK: The 'cult-like' beauty businesses in your DMs
item.description: Newsbeat hears from young women about their experiences working for multi-level marketing companies.

item.title: Budget 2021: 'My benefits top-up is a lifeline - don't take it away'
item.description: A benefits top-up to help the poor survive lockdown is due to end - unless it is extended at the Budget.

item.title: Maximo Park on Grenfell, the Bataclan and fatherhood
item.description: The North East indie-pop band say music can both "celebrate life" and ask "difficult questions".

item.title: Vintage technology: 'It sounds so much cleaner'
item.description: Why do people like to use ancient personal organisers and music players?

item.title: Analysis: Can Asia help Myanmar find a way out of coup crisis?
item.description: While Western sanctions may not help, China and South East Asia's influence may hold some sway.

item.title: 'Life was a party before Aids arrived in London'
item.description: Gay life in London was vibrant as the 1980s began, but a mysterious illness was soon to change that.

item.title: Ronnie O'Sullivan reaches record 57th ranking final at Players Championship
item.description: Ronnie O'Sullivan comes from 3-0 down to beat Barry Hawkins 6-4 and reach a record-equalling 57th ranking event final in the Players Championship.

item.title: Derby 'disgusted' by online racist abuse of striker Kazim-Richards
item.description: Derby County striker Colin Kazim-Richards received racist abuse after Friday's draw with Nottingham Forest, the club says.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The prime minister has announced a plan for how the lockdown will be lifted in England.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 19 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: How are weddings working around the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid vaccine phase two groups: When will I get vaccinated?
item.description: After phase one is complete by mid-April, here's the order in which all other adults will get the jab.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday in the UK or travel abroad?
item.description: The government has unveiled its plans for unlocking UK restrictions, including holiday travel.

item.title: Ipswich lockdown litter artist aims to inspire UK clean-up
item.description: Giant garden murals made from rubbish and discarded PPE gain thousands of social media views.

item.title: Lockdown exit plan: 'Why we can't wait to get back on the pitch'
item.description: With outdoor sport hopefully set to resume in March, Newsbeat hears about the importance of playing football.

item.title: IVF: How one single man hopes to become a father
item.description: Stephen Dyer says he will "do anything" to become a parent - including a bill of up to £40,000.

item.title: Long Covid: 'I can't walk 10m without a rest'
item.description: Three people tell the BBC how the condition has affected their physical and mental health.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid lockdown eye strain
item.description: In lockdown, days on end can be spent staring at a screen, which is taking its toll on people's eyes.
